Issues.Title: FileDialog/FolderBrowserDialog should fall back to legacy dialog on COMException
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: `master` (7dee30995829711ac3a486f672cede1171ab4eb1)
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**

When [`FileDialog.AutoUpgradeEnabled`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.filedialog.autoupgradeenabled?view=netcore-3.1)/[`FolderBrowserDialog.AutoUpgradeEnabled`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.folderbrowserdialog.autoupgradeenabled?view=netcore-3.1) is `true` (the default), the newer COM-based Vista File Dialog will be shown instead of the legacy file dialog.

However, on Windows Server that was installed using the "Server Core" option, these COM components may not available. While Server Core normally isn't suited to run GUI applications, you can install the [**Server Core App Compatibility Feature on Demand (FOD)**](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/get-started-19/install-fod-19) package that improves compatibility for GUI applications by installing additional components, including `explorer.exe` (as file browser).

While that package normally also installs the COM components required to show the Vista file dialog, in some cases (e.g. after installing certain Windows Updates) these components can become unavailable again, and the Vista File Dialog will no longer work. 

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
When the COM components required for the Vista file dialog are not available, calling `OpenFileDialog.ShowDialog()` results in a `COMException` (`CLASS_E_CLASSNOTAVAILABLE`):

```
System.Runtime.InteropServices.COMException (0x80040111): Creating an instance of the COM component with CLSID {DC1C5A9C-E88A-4DDE-A5A1-60F82A20AEF7} from the IClassFactory failed due to the following error: 80040111 ClassFactory cannot supply requested class (0x80040111 (CLASS_E_CLASSNOTAVAILABLE)).
   at System.Windows.Forms.OpenFileDialog.CreateVistaDialog()
   at System.Windows.Forms.FileDialog.RunDialogVista(IntPtr hWndOwner)
   at System.Windows.Forms.FileDialog.RunDialog(IntPtr hWndOwner)
   at System.Windows.Forms.CommonDialog.ShowDialog(IWin32Window owner)
   at System.Windows.Forms.CommonDialog.ShowDialog()
```

A similar stack occurs for `FolderBrowserDialog.ShowDialog()`:
```
System.Runtime.InteropServices.COMException (0x80040111): Creating an instance of the COM component with CLSID {DC1C5A9C-E88A-4DDE-A5A1-60F82A20AEF7} from the IClassFactory failed due to the following error: 80040111 ClassFactory cannot supply requested class (0x80040111 (CLASS_E_CLASSNOTAVAILABLE)).
   at System.Windows.Forms.FolderBrowserDialog.RunDialogVista(IntPtr owner)
   at System.Windows.Forms.FolderBrowserDialog.RunDialog(IntPtr hWndOwner
   at System.Windows.Forms.CommonDialog.ShowDialog(IWin32Window owner)
   at System.Windows.Forms.CommonDialog.ShowDialog()
```


**Expected behavior:**
When instantiating the COM object fails, I think the dialog should automatically fall back to the legacy file dialog, which seems to be done by most native applications like `notepad.exe` (see repro steps).
This will allow WinForms applications using a `FileDialog` or `FolderBrowserDialog` to work correctly on Windows Server Core with App Compatibility FOD installed, instead of crashing due to the `COMException`.


**Minimal repro:**
* Install Windows Server 2019 (using ISO image from [MS Evaluation Center](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/evalcenter/evaluate-windows-server-2019)), using option `Windows Server 2019 Standard Evaluation` (not with "Desktop Experience").
* After installation is finished, install the [Server Core App Compatibility FOD](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/get-started-19/install-fod-19) in Powershell with `Add-WindowsCapability -Online -Name ServerCore.AppCompatibility~~~~0.0.1.0`, and then restart the machine.
* On another machine, create a new WinForms app with `dotnet new winforms` and use the following code in `Program.cs`:
```c#
using System;
using System.Windows.Forms;

class Program
{
    [STAThread]
    static void Main()
    {
        Application.EnableVisualStyles();
        Application.SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault(false);

        var dialog = new OpenFileDialog();
        dialog.ShowDialog();
    }
}
```
* Publish the app with `dotnet publish -f netcoreapp5.0 -r win-x64`.
* Copy the published app to the Windows Server machine and run it.
* Notice the file dialog is correctly shown using the Vista file dialog. Also, when you start `notepad.exe` and select `File`->`Open`, it shows the Vista file dialog:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13289184/70863732-5b1f2f00-1f4b-11ea-9486-b974fc86f084.png)
* Now download and install [`2019-12 Cumulative Update for Windows Server 2019 for x64-based Systems (KB4530715)`](https://www.catalog.update.microsoft.com/Search.aspx?q=KB4530715), and restart the machine.
* Run the app again. Notice it fails with a **`COMException`** (see stacktrace above).
* When running `notepad.exe` and selecting `File`->`Open`, you can see that the legacy file dialog is shown:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13289184/70863741-8d309100-1f4b-11ea-92cb-b5a6d9cda9cc.png)

**Workaround**

You can work around the issue by catching `COMException` and disabling `AutoUpgradeEnabled`:
```c#
        try
        {
            dialog.ShowDialog();
        }
        catch (COMException) when (dialog.AutoUpgradeEnabled)
        {
            dialog.AutoUpgradeEnabled = false;
            try
            {
                dialog.ShowDialog();
            }
            finally
            {
                dialog.AutoUpgradeEnabled = true;
            }
        }
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "FileDialog/FolderBrowserDialog should fall back to legacy dialog on COMException" (#2506)

Issues.Title: Read me for Visual Studio and Core releases do not highlight breaking changes
Issues.Body: There are (breaking) changes between Framework and Core that are hard to discover. Until today I did not know there was a GitHub documentation: breaking tag with some of that information. While this is great for details this is terrible for discovery. So far I have found out Core has new default font, there are significant and great changes in FolderDialogBrowser, DataGridView Heading have different behavior, Version 16.5.0 Preview 1.0 designer supports VB and this is just to name a few. NONE are bugs IMHO, they are improvements that people need to know about and in some cases before installing and not tripped on.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Read me for Visual Studio and Core releases do not highlight breaking changes" (#2501)

Issues.Title: Fix DivideByZeroException in MonthCalendar
Issues.Body:
## Proposed Changes
- If `SingleMonthSize` is a certain size, (e.g. `new Size(6, 6)`) then a `DivideByZeroException` is thrown.
- Fix this by avoiding the `DivideByZeroException` by not checking for this case and not dividing by zero

Extracted from https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/2482

Issues.Title: Revert versions to f3ac1266 level, where MicrosoftNETCoreApppackageVersion=5.0.0-alpha1.19514.1
Issues.Body:
Temporarily, revert versions to [f3ac1266 ](https://github.com/wpfcontrib/winforms/commit/f3ac1266) level, where `MicrosoftNETCoreApppackageVersion=5.0.0-alpha1.19514.1`. 

This version is very likely compatible with the WPF repo right now.

--

In https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/2118, transport packages originating from WinForms are unable to build successfully due to a CoreCLR + Compiler problem. This prevents WinForms work from flowing into [dotnet/windowsdesktop](https://github.com/dotnet/windowsdesktop) and ultimately into [dotnet/core-sdk](https://github.com/dotnet/core-sdk). 

WPF currently ingests `Microsoft.NETCore.App` version `5.0.0-alpha1.19514.1` - this can be seen in the LHS of `eng/Version.Detail.xml` in https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/pull/2118/files. This version comes from WinForms through a `CoherentParentDependency` like this: 

```xml
    <Dependency Name="Microsoft.NETCore.App" Version="5.0.0-alpha1.19514.1" CoherentParentDependency="Microsoft.Private.Winforms">
```

If WinForms repo were moved back temporarily to this version of `Microsoft.NETCore.App`, then the packages it would subsequently flow into WPF ought to build cleanly, and then flow all the way to dotnet/windowsdesktop and later onto dotnet/core-sdk. 

Once WPF gets fixes for C++ compiler and corresponding updates for CoreCLR (which could take a while), WinForms can fast-forward to building against latest versions of CoreFx/CoreCLR. 


/cc @RussKie, @AdamYoblick, @merriemcgaw 
/cc @rladuca 


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/2497)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Revert versions to f3ac1266 level, where MicrosoftNETCoreApppackageVersion=5.0.0-alpha1.19514.1" (#2497)

Issues.Title: The value of SplitterWidth cannot be set successfully after changing the SplitterConatiner .SplitterWidth
Issues.Body:
.NET Core Version: .NET Core 3.1.101-servicing-014750 from Release branch + the VSIX Inserted into Dev16 16.5.0 Preview 2.0 [29605.132.master]
Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

**More Info:**
1.	This issue can reproduce with .Net Framework project from .Net4.0 to latest .Net4.8.
2.	This issue cannot reproduce if SplitterConatiner isn’t within panel container.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1.	Launch VS and create a .Net Framework project.
2.	Add a Panel to the form, and drag and drop a SplitterConatiner to Panel.
3.	Set SplitterWidth property of SplitterConatiner in property browser window to 8 (or something other than 4).
4.	In Form1_Load event add this.splitContainer1.SplitterWidth.ToString();
5.	Migrate the code of Framework app to Core app, and run the core app.
[SplitterContainer_SplitterWidth.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3937691/SplitterContainer_SplitterWidth.zip)

**Actual Result:**
SplitContainer1.SplitterWidth return 4 not 8 after running the app.
![SplitterWidth_Core](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/70403677-89e06580-1a72-11ea-95ad-a7d5218c3860.png)

**Expected Result:**
SplitContainer1.SplitterWidth should return 8 after running the app.
![SplitterWidth_Expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/70403682-8cdb5600-1a72-11ea-944f-bf757a672777.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The value of SplitterWidth cannot be set successfully after changing the SplitterConatiner .SplitterWidth" (#2490)
